editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

editorialDecl.p: These texts have been encoded in TEI Simple, but retain all the structural distinctions found in the TCP texts fron which they were derived. The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: I never saw the like, she's no more stirred,
No more another woman, no more altered,
With any hopes or promises laid to her
(Let 'em be never so weighty, never so winning,
Than I am with the motion of my own legs.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Chilax.
You are a stranger yet in these designs,
At least in Rome; tell me, and tell me truth,
Did you ere know in all your course of practice,
In all the ways of woman you have run through
(For I presume you have been brought up Chilax,
As we to fetch and carry.)

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: True I have so:

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Did you I say again in all this progress,
Ever discover such a piece of beauty,
Ever so rare a creature, and no doubt
One that must know her worth too, and affect it,
I and be flattered, else 'tis none: and honest?
Honest against the tide of all temptations,
Honest to one man, to her husband only,
And yet not eighteen, not of age to know
Why she is honest?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I confess it freely,
I never saw her fellow, nor e'er shall,
For all our Grecian dames, all I have tried,
(And sure I have tried a hundred, if I say two
I speak within my compass) all these beauties,
And all the constancy of all these faces,
Maids, widows, wives, of what degree or calling,
So they be Greeks, and fat, for there's my cunning,
I would undertake and not sweat for't, Proculus,
Were they to try again, say twice as many,
Under a thousand pound, to lay 'em bedrid;
But this wench staggers me.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Do you see these jewels?
You would think these pretty baits; now I'll assure ye
Here's half the wealth of Asia.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: These are nothing
To the full honours I propounded to her;
I bid her think, and be, and presently
Whatever her ambition, what the council
Of others would add to her, what her dreams
Could more enlarge, what any precedent
Of any woman rising up to glory,
And standing certain there, and in the highest,
Could give her more, nay to be empress.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And cold at all these offers?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Cold as crystal,
Never to be thawed again,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I tried her further,
And so far, that I think she is no woman,
At least as women go now.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Why what did you?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I offered that, that had she been but mistress
Of as much spleen as doves have, I had reached her ▪
A safe revenge of all that ever hates her,
The crying down for ever all beauties
That may be thought come near her.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: That was pretty.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I never knew that way fail, yet I'll tell ye
I offered her a gift beyond all yours,
That, that had made a saint start, well considered,
The law to be her creature, she to make it,
Her mouth to give it, every creature living
From her aspect, to draw their good or evil
Fixed in 'em spite of fortune; a new nature
She should be called, and mother of all ages,
Time should be hers, and what she did lame virtue
Should bless to all posterities: her air
Should give us life, her earth and water feed us.
And last, to none but to the emperor,
(And then but when she pleased to have it so,)
She should be held for mortal.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: And she heard you?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Yes, as a sick man hears a noise, or he
That stands condemned his judgement, let me perish,
But if there can be virtue, if that name
Be any thing but name and empty title,
If it be so as fools have been pleased to saigne it,
A power that can preserve us after ashes,
And make the names of men out-reckon ages,
This woman has a god of virtue in her.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: I would the emperor were that God.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: She has in her
All the contempt of glory and vain seeming
Of all the Stoics, all the truth of Christians,
And all their constancy: modesty was made
When she was first intended: when she blushes
It is the holiest thing to look upon;
The purest temple of her sect, that ever
Made nature a blessed founder.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Is there no way
To take this phoenix?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: None but in her ashes.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: If she were fat, or any way inclining
To ease or pleasure, or effected glory,
Proud to be seen and worshipped, 'twere a venture;
But on my soul she is chaster than cold camphire.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: I think so too; for all the ways of woman,
Like a full sail she bears against: I ask her
After my many offers, walking with her,
And her as many down-denials, how
If the emperor grown mad with love should force her;
She pointed to a Lucrece, that hung by,
And with an angry look, that from her eyes
Shot vestal fire against me, she departed.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: This is the first wench I was ever posed in,
Yet I have brought young loving things together
This two and thirty year.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I find by this wench
The calling of a bawd to be a strange,
A wise, and subtle calling; and for none
But stayed, discreet, and understanding people:
And as the tutor to great Alexander,
Would say a young man should not dare to read
His moral books, till after five and twenty;
So must that he or she, that will be bawdy,
(I mean discreetly bawdy, and be trusted)
If they will rise, and gain experience,
Well steeped in years, and discipline, begin it,
I take it 'tis no boys play.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Well, what's thought off?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: The emperor must know it.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: If the women should chance to fail too,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: As 'tis ten to one,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Why what remains, but new nets for the purchase?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Let's go consider then: and if all fail,
This is the first quick eel, that saved her tail. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ardelia.
sp.l: You still insist upon that idol, honour,
Can it renew your youth, can it add wealth,
That takes off wrinkles: can it draw men's eyes,
To gaze upon you in your age? can honour,
That truly is a saint to none but soldiers,
And looked into, bear no reward but danger,
Leave you the most respected person living?
Or can the common kisses of a husband,
(Which to a sprightly lady is a labour)
Make ye almost immortal? ye are cozened,
The honour of a woman is her praises;
The way to get these, to be seen, and sought too,
And not to bury such a happy sweetness
Under a smoky roof.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: I'll hear no more:

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.l: That white, and red, and all that blessed beauty,
Kept from the eyes, that make it so, is nothing;
Than you are rarely fair, when men proclaim it;
The phoenix, were she never seen, were doubted,
That most unvalued horn the unicorn
Bears to oppose the huntsman, were it nothing
But tale, and mere tradition, would help no man,
But when the virtue's known, the honour's doubled:
Virtue, is either lame, or not at all,
And love a sacrilege, and not a saint,
When it bars up the way to men's petitions.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Nay ye shall love your husband too; we come not
To make a monster of ye;

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Are ye women?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: You'll find us so, and women you shall think too,
If you have grace to make your use.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Eye on ye,

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.l: Alas poor bashful lady, by my soul,
Had ye no other virtue, but your blushes,
And I a man, I should run mad for those;
How daintily they set her off, how sweetly?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Come goddess, come, you move too near the earth,
It must not be, a better orb stays for you:
Here: be a maid, and taken,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pray leave me.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.l: That were a sin sweet lady, and a way
To make us guilty of your melancholy;
You must not be alone; in conversation
Doubts are resolved, and what sticks near the conscience
Made easy, and allowable.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ye are devils,

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: That you may one day bless for your damnation.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I charge ye in the name of chastity,
Tempt me no more; how ugly ye seem to me?
There is no wonder men defame our sex,
And lay the vices of all ages on us,
When such as you shall bear the names of women;
If ye had eyes to see yourselves, or sense
Above the base rewards ye play the bawds for:
If ever in your lives ye heard of goodness,
(Though many regions off, as men hear thunder)
If ever ye had mothers, and they souls:
If ever fathers, and not such as you are;
If ever any thing were constant in you,
Beside your sins, or coming but your curses,
If ever any of your ancestors
Died worth a noble deed, that would be cherished,
Soul-frighted with this black infection,
You would run from one another, to repentance,
And from your guilty eyes drop out those sins,
That made ye blind, and beasts.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.l: Ye speak well lady;
A sign of fruitful education,
If your religious zeal had wisdom with it.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: This lady was ordained to bless the empire,
And we may all give thanks for't.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.l: I believe ye,

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: If any thing redeem the emperor,
From his wild flying courses, this is she;
She can instruct him if ye mark; she is wise too.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.l: Exceeding wise, which is a wonder in her,
And so religious, that I well believe,
Though she would sin she cannot.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: And, besides
She has the empire's cause in hand, not loves;
There lies the main consideration,
For which she is chiefly born.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.l: She finds that point
Stronger than we can tell her, and believe it
I look by her means for a reformation,
And such a one, and such a rare way carried
That all the world shall wonder at.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: 'Tis true;
I never thought the emperor had wisdom,
Pity, or fair affection to his country,
Till he professed this love: gods give 'em children,
Such as her virtue's merit, and his zeal.
I look to see a Numa from this lady,
Or greater than Octavius.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.l: Do you mark too,
Which is a noble virtue, how she blushes,
And what a flowing modesty runs through her,
When we but name the emperor?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: But mark it,
Yes, and admire it too, for she considers,
Though she be fair as heaven, and virtuous
As holy truth, yet to the emperor
She is a kind of nothing but her service,
Which she is bound to offer, and she'll do it,
And when her country's cause commands affection;
She knows obedience is the key of virtues,
Then fly the blushes out like Cupid's arrows,
And though the tie of marriage to her lord,
Would fain cry stay Lucina, yet the cause
And general wisdom of the prince's love,
Makes her find surer ends and happier,
And if the first were chaste, this is twice doubled.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.l: Her tartness unto us too.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: That's a wise one.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.l: I rarely like, it shows a rising wisdom,
That chides all common fools as dare inquire
What princes would have private.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: What a lady
Shall we be blessed to serve?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Go get ye from me.
Ye are your purses agents, not the princes:
Is this the virtuous lore ye trained me out too?
Am I a woman fit to imp your vices?
But that I had a mother, and a woman
Whose ever living fame turns all it touches,
Into the good itself is, I should now
Even doubt myself, I have been searched so near
The very soul of honour: why should you two,
That happily have been as chaste as I am,
Fairer, I think, by much, for yet your faces,
Like ancient well built piles, show worthy ruins,
After that angel age, turn mortal devils?
For shame, for womanhood, for what ye have been,
For rotten cedars have born goodly branches,
If ye have hope of any heaven, but court,
Which like a dream, you'll find hereafter vanish,
Or at the best but subject to repentance,
Study no more to be ill spoken of;
Let women live themselves, if they must fall,
Their own destruction find 'em, not your sevours.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Madam, ye are so excellent in all,
And I must tell it you with admiration,
So true a joy ye have, so sweet a fear,
And when ye come to anger, 'tis so noble,
That for mine own part, I could still offend,
To hear you angry; women that want that,
And your way guided (Else I count it nothing)
Are either fools, or cowards.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.l: She were a mistress for no private greatness,
Could she not frown a ravished kiss from anger,
And such an anger as this lady learns us,
Stuck with such pleasing dangers. Gods (I ask ye)
Which of ye all could hold from?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I perceive ye,
Your own dark sins dwell with ye, and that price
You sell the chastity of modest wives at
Runs to diseases with your bones: I scorn ye,
And all the nets ye have pitched to catch my virtues
Like spiders webs, I sweep away before me.
Go tell the emperor, ye have met a woman,
That neither his own person, which is godlike,
The world he rules, nor what that world can purchase,
Nor all the glories, subject to a Cesar,
The honours that he offers for my body,
The hopes, gifts, everlasting flatteries,
Nor any thing that's his, and apt to tempt me,
No not to be the mother of the empire,
And Queen of all the holy fires he worships,
Can make a whore of.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: You mistake us lady.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Yet tell him this has thus much weakened me,
That I have here his knaves, and you his matrons,
Fit nurses for his sins, which gods forgive me,
But ever to be leaning to his folly,
Or to be brought to love his lust, assure him,
And from her mouth, whose life shall make it certain
I never can: I have a noble husband,
Pray tell him that too, yet a noble name,
A noble family, and last a conscience:
Thus much for your answer: for yourselves,
Ye have lived the shame of women, die the better,Exit

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.l: What's now to do? Lucina.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: E'en as she said, to die,
For there's no living here, and women thus,
I am sure for us two.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.l: Nothing stick upon her?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: We have lost a mass of money; well dame virtue,
Yet ye may halt if good luck serve.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.l: Worms take her,
She has almost spoiled our trade.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: So godly;
This is ill breeding Phorba.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.l: If the women
Should have a longing now to see this monster,
And she convert 'em all,

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: That may be Phorba,
But if it be, I'll have the young men gelded:
Come, let's go think, she must not scape us thus;
There is a certain season, if we hit,
That women may be rid without a bit. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: I cannot blame the nations noble friend,
That they fall off so fast from this wild man,
When (Under our allegiance be it spoken,
And the most happy tie of our affections)
The world's weight groans beneath him; where lives virtue,
Honour, discretion, wisdom? who are called
And chosen to the stleering of the empire
But bawds, and singing girls? O my Aecius,
The glory or a soldier, and the truth
Of men made up for goodness' sake, like shells
Grow to the ragged walls for want of action:
Only your happy self, and I that love ye,
Which is a larger means to me then favour.

sp.speaker: Aecius
sp.l: No more my worthy friend, though these be truths,
And though these truth's would ask a reformation,
At least a little squaring; yet remember,
We are but subjects Maximus; obedience
To what is done, and grief for what is ill done,
Is all we can call ours: the hearts of princes
Are like the temples of the gods; pure incense,
Until unhallowed hands defile those offerings,
Burns ever there; we must not put 'em out,
Because the priests that touch those sweets are wicked;
We dare not dearest friend, nay more we cannot,
While we consider why we are, and how,
To what laws bound, much more to what lawgiver;
Whilst majesty is made to be obeyed,
And not inquired into, whilst gods and angels
Make but a rule as we do, though a stricter;
Like desperate and unseasoned fools let fly
Our killing angers, and forsake our honours.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: My noble friend, from whose instructions
I never yet took surfeit, weigh but thus much,
Nor think I speak it with ambition,
For by the gods I do not, why Aecius,
Why are we thus, or how become thus wretched?

sp.speaker: Aecius.
sp.l: You'll fall again into your fit.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: I will not.
Or are we now no more the sons of Romans,
No more the followers of their happy fortunes,
But conquered Gaules, or quivers for the Parthians?
Why is this emperor, this man we honour,
This God that ought to be?

sp.speaker: Aecius.
sp.l: You are too curious.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Good, give me leave, why is this author of us?

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: I dare not hear ye speak thus.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: I'll be modest,
Thus led away, thus vainly led away,
And we beholders, misconceive me not,
I sow no danger in my words; but wherefore
And to what end, are we the sons of fathers
Famous, and fast to Rome? Why are their virtues
Stamped in the dangers of a thousand battles,
For goodness' sake, their honours, time out daring,
I think for our example.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Ye speak nobly.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Why are we seeds of these then, to shake hands
With bawds and base informers, kiss discredit,
And court her like a mistress? pray, your leave yet;
You'll say the emperor is young, and apt
To take impression rather from his pleasures
Then any constant worthiness, it may be.
But why do these, the people call his pleasures,
Exceed the moderation of a man?
Nay to say justly friend, why are they vices
And such as shake our worths with foreign nations?

sp.speaker: Aec.
sp.l: You search the sore too deep, and I must tell ye,
In any other man this had been boldness,
And so rewarded; pray depress you spirit,
For though I constantly believe ye honest,
Ye were no friend for me else, and what now
Ye freely spoke, but good ye owe tooth empire,
Yet take heed worthy Maximus, all ears
Hear not with that distinction mine do, few
You'll find admonishers, but urgers of your actions,
And to the heaviest (Friend;) and pray consider
We are but shadows, motions others give us,
And though our pities may become the times,
Justly our powers cannot; make me worthy
To be your ever friend in fair allegiance,
But not in force: for durst mine own soul urge me
(And by that soul, I speak my just affections)
To turn my hand from truth, which is obedience,
And give the helm my virtue holds, to anger,
Though I had both the blessings of the brutij,
And both their instigations, though my cause
Carried a face of justice beyond theirs,
And as I am a servant to my fortunes,
That daring soul, that first taught disobedience,
Should feel the first example: say the prince,
As I may well believe, seems vicious,
Who justly knows 'tis not to try our honours?
Or say he be an ill prince, are we therefore
Fit fires to purge him? No, my dearest friend
The elephant is never won with anger,
Nor must that man that would reclaim a lion,
Take him by'th teeth.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: I pray mistake me not.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Our honest actions, and the light that breaks
Like morning from our service, chaste and blushing
Is that, that pulls a prince back; then he sees,
And not till then truly repents his errors,
When subjects' crystal souls are glasses to him.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: My ever honoured friend, I'll take your council:
The emperor appears, I'll leave ye to him,
And as we both affect him, may he flourish. Exit Max.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.p: Is that the best news? Enter the emperor and Chilax.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Yet the best we know sir.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Bid Maximus come to me, and be gone then:
Mine own head be my helper, these are fools;
How now Aecius, are the soldiers quiet?

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Better I hope sir, than they were.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: They are pleased I hear,
To censure me extremely for my pleasures,
Shortly they'll fight against me.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Gods defend sir.
And for their censures they are such shrewd judgers;
A donative of ten sesterties
I'll undertake shall make 'em ring your praises,
More than they sang your pleasures.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: I believe thee.
Art thou in love Aecius yet?

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: O no sir.
I am too course for ladies; my embraces
That only am acquainted with alarms,
Would break their tender bodies.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Never fear it,
They are stronger than ye think, they'll hold the hammer
My empress swears thou art a lusty soldier,
A good one I believe thee.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: All that goodness
Is but your grace's creature.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Tell me truly,
For thou dar'st tell me.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Any thing concerns ye,
That's fit for me to speak and you to pardon.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: What say the soldiers of me, and the same words,
Mince 'em not good Aecius, but deliver
The very forms and tongues they talk withal,

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: I'll tell your grace, but with this caution
You be not stirred, for should the gods live with us,
Even those we certainly believe are righteous.
Give 'em but drink, they would censure them too.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Forward.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Then to begin, they say you sleep too much
By which they judge your majesty too sensual,
Apt to decline your strength to ease and pleasures,
And when you do not sleep, you drink too much,
From which they fear suspicions first, than ruins;
And when ye neither drink nor sleep, ye wench much,
Which they affirm first breaks your understanding,
Then takes the edge of honour, make us seem,
That are the ribs, and rampires of the empire,
Fencers, and beaten fools, and so regarded;
But I believe 'em not; for were these truths,
Your virtue can correct them.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: They speak plainly.

sp.speaker: Aec.
sp.l: They say moreover (Since your grace will have it,
For they will talk their freedoms, though the sword
Were in their throat) that of late time, like Nero,
And with the same forgetfulness of glory,
You have got a vain of filing, so they term it.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Some drunken dreams Aecius.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: So I hope sir.
And that you rather study cruelty,
And to be feared for blood, then loved for bounty.
Which makes the nations, as they say, despise ye,
Telling your years and actions by their deaths,
Whose truth, and strength of duty made you Caesar.
They say besides you nourish strange devourers,
Fed with the fat o'th empires, they call bawds,
Lazy and lustful creatures that abuse ye,
A people as they term 'em, made of paper,
In which the secret sins of each man's moneys
Are sealed and sent a working.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: What sin's next?
For I perceive they have no mind to spare me.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Nor hurt ye o my soul sir; but such people
(Nor can the power of man restrain it)
When they are full of meat and ease, must prattle.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Forward.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: I have spoken too much sir.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: I'll have all.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: It fits not
Your ears should hear their vanities; no profit
Can justly rise to you from their behaviour,
Unless ye were guilty of those crimes.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: It may be
I am so, therefore forward.

sp.speaker: Aeci
sp.l: I have ever
Learned to obey, nor shall my life resist it.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: No more apologies.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: They grieve besides sir,
To see the nations, whom our ancient virtue
With many a weary march and hunger conquered,
With loss of many a daring life subdued,
Fall from their fair obedience, and even murmur
To see the warlike eagles mew their honours
In obscure towns, that wont to prey on princes,
They cry for enemies, and tell the captains
The fruits of Italy are luscious, give us Egypt,
Or sandy Afrique to display our valours,
There where our swords may make us meat, and danger
Digest our well got viands: here our weapons
And bodies that were made for shining brass,
Are both unedged and old with ease, and women;
And than they cry again, where are the Germans,
Lined with hot Spain, or Gallia, bring 'em on,
And let the son of war, steeled Mithridates,
Lead up his winged Parthians like a storm,
Hiding the face of heaven with showers of arrows;
Yet we dare fight like Romans; then as soldiers
Tired with a weary march, they tell their wounds
Even weeeping ripe they were no more nor deeper,
And glory in those scars that make 'em lovely,
And sitting where a camp was, like sad pilgrims
They reckon up the times, and living labours
Of Julius or Germanicus, and wonder
That Rome, whose turrets once were topped with honours,
Can now forget the custom of her conquests:
And then they blame your grace, and say who leads us,
Shall we stand here like statues? were our fathers
The sons of lazy Moors, our princes Persians,
Nothing but silks, and softness? curses on 'em
That first taught Nero wantonness, and blood,
Tiberius' doubts, Caligula all vices;
For from the spring of these succeeding princes
Thus they talk sir;

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Well,
Why do you hear these things?

sp.speaker: Aec.
sp.l: Why do you do 'em?
I take the gods to witness, with more sorrow,
And more vexation, do I hear these taintures,
Then were my life dropped from me through an hourglass

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Belike than you believe 'em, or at least
Are glad they should be so; take heed, you were better
Build your own tomb, and run into it living,
Then dare a prince's anger.

sp.speaker: Aec.
sp.l: I am old sir,
And ten years more addition, is but nothing:
Now if my life be pleasing to ye, take it,
Upon my knees, if ever any service,
As let me brag, some have been worthy notice,
If ever any worth, or trust ye gave me,
Deserved a fair respect, if all my actions,
The hazards of my youth, colds, burnings, wants,
For you and for the empire, be not vices,
By that style ye have stamped upon me, soldier,
Let me not fall into the hands of wretches.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: I understand ye not.

sp.speaker: Aec.
sp.l: Let not this body,
That has looked bravely in his blood for Cesar,
And covetous of wounds, and for your safety,
After the scape of swords, spears, slings, and arrows,
'Gainst which my beaten body was mine armour,
The seas, and thirsty deserts, now be purchase
For slaves, and base informers: I see anger,
And death look through your eyes: I am marked for slaughter
And know the telling of this truth has made me
A man clean lost to this world; I embrace it;
Only my last petition sacred Cesar,
Is, I may die a roman.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Rise my friend still,
And worthy of my love; reclaim the soldier,
I'll study to do so upon myself too,
Go keep your command, and prosper.

sp.speaker: Aec.
sp.p: Life to Cesar— Exit Aecius — enter Chilax.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Lord Maximus attends your grace.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Go tell him,
I'll meet him in the gallery.
The honesty of this Aecius
Who is indeed the bulwark of the empire,
Has dived so deep into me, that of all
The sins I covet, but this woman's beauty,
With much repentance, now I could be quit of:
But she is such a pleasure, being good,
That though I were a god, she would fire my blood.Exit

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter the emperor, Maximus, Lycinius, Proculus, Chilax, as at dice.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Nay ye shall set my hand out, 'tis not just
I should neglect my fortune, now 'tis prosperous.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: If I have any thing to set your grace,
But clothes or good conditions, let me perish,
You have all my money sir;

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And mine,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And mine too.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Unless your grace will credit us,

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: No bare board,

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Then at my garden-house;

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: The orchard too.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: An't please your grace,

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Have at 'em,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: They are lost;

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Why farewell figtrees,

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Who sets more?

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: At my horse sir,

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: The dappled Spaniard?

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: He.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: He's mine,

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: He is so;

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Your shorthorse is soon curried:

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: So it seems sir,
So may your mare be too, if luck serve.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Nothing my lord but grieving at my fortune,

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Come Maximus, you were not wont to flinch thus

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: By heaven sir, I have lost all.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: There's a ring yet,

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: This was not made to lose sir,

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Some love token;
Set it I say;

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: I do beseech your grace,
Rather name any house I have.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: How strange,
And curious you are grown of toys? redeem't
If so I win it, when you please, tomorrow,
Or next day as ye will, I care not,
But only for my luck's sake: 'tis not rings
Can make me richer.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Will you throw sir? there 'tis:

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Why then have at it fairly: mine.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Your grace
Is only ever fortunate: tomorrow,
An't be your pleasure sir, I'll pay the price on't;

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Tomorrow you shall have it without price sir,
But this day 'tis my victory: good Maximus,
Now I bethink myself, go to Aecius,
And bid him muster all the cohorts presently;
They mutiny for pay I hear, and be you
Assistant to him; when you know their numbers,
Ye shall have moneys for 'em, and above
Something to stop their tongues withal.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: I will sir,
And gods preserve you in this mind still.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Shortly I'll see 'em march myself.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: God's ever keep ye. — exit Max.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: To what end do you think this ring shall serve now?
For you are fellows only know by rote,
As birds record their lessons.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: For the lady,

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: But how for her?

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: That I confess I know not,

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Then pray for him that does: fetch me an eunuch
That never saw her yet: and you two see. Exit. Chil.
The court made like a paradise.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: We will sir.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Full of fair shows and musics; all your arts
(As I shall give instructions) screw to'th highest,
For my main piece is now a doing: and for fear
You should not take, I'll have another engine,
Such as if virtue be not only in her,
She shall not choose but lean to, let the women
Put on a graver show of welcome.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Well sir.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.p: They are a thought too eager. —Enter Chilax and Lycias the eunuch.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Here's the eunuch,

sp.speaker: Eunuch
sp.l: Long life to Cesar.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: I must use you Lycias:
Come let's walk in, and then I'll show ye all:
If women may be frail, this wench shall fall. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Claudia.
sp.l: Sirrah, what ails my lady, that of late
She never cares for company?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I know not,
Unless it be that company causes cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: That were a childish fear;

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What were those ladies,
Came to her lately,
From the court?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: The same wench.
Some grave instructors on my life, they look
For all the world like old hatched hilts.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis true wench.
For here and there, and yet they painted well too,
One might discover where the gold was worn
Their iron ages.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: If my judgement fail not,
They have been sheathed like rotten ships,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It may be.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: For if ye mark their rudders, they hang weakly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They have passed the line belike: wouldst live Clau
Till thou wert such as they are?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Chimney pieces.
Now heaven have mercy on me, and young men,
I had rather make a drallery till thirty,
While I were able to endure a tempest,
And bear my fights out bravely, till my tackle.
Whistled i'th wind, and held against all weathers,
While I were able to bear with my tires
And so discharge 'em, I would willingly
Live Marcellina, not till barnacles
Bred in my sides.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thou art i'th right wench.
For who would live, whom pleasures had forsaken,
To stand at mark, and cry a bow short signeur?
Were there not men came hither too?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Brave fellows.
I fear me bawds of five i'th' pound.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How know you?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: They gave me great lights to it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Take heed Claudia.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Let them take heed, the spring comes on.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To me now,
They seemed as noble visitants.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: To me now
Nothing less Marcellina, for I mark 'em,
And by this honest light, for yet 'tis morning,
Saving the reverence of their guilded doublets
And Milan skins.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thou art a strange wench Claudia.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Ye are deceived, they showed to me directly
Court crabs that creep aside way for their living
I know 'em by the breeches that they begged last,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Peace, my lady comes; what may that be?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: A sumnerEnter Lucina, and Lycias the eunuch.
That cites her to appear.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No more of that wench.

sp.speaker: Eunuch
sp.l: Madam, what answer to your lord?

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Pray tell him, I am subject to his will,

sp.speaker: Eunuch
sp.l: Why weep you madam?
Excellent lady, there are none will hurt you.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: I do beseech you tell me sir.

sp.speaker: Eunuch
sp.l: What lady?

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Serve ye the emperor?

sp.speaker: Eunuch
sp.l: I do.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: In what place?

sp.speaker: Eunuch
sp.l: In's chamber madam.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Do ye serve his will too?

sp.speaker: Eunuch
sp.l: In fair and just commands.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Are ye a Roman?

sp.speaker: Eunuch
sp.l: Yes noble lady, and a Mantuan.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: What office bore your parents?

sp.speaker: Eunuch
sp.l: One was praetor.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Take heed then how you stain his reputation,

sp.speaker: Eunuch
sp.l: Why worthy lady?

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: If ye know, I charge ye,
Ought in this message, but what honesty,
The trust and fair obedience of a servant,
May well deliver, yet take heed, and help me.

sp.speaker: Eunuch
sp.l: Madam, I am no broker;

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I'll be hanged then.

sp.speaker: Eunuch
sp.l: Nor base procurer of men's lusts; your husband,
Prayed me to do this office, I have done it,
It rests in you to come, or no:

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I will sir;

sp.speaker: Eunuch
sp.l: If ye mistrust me, do not,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ye appear so worthy,
And to all my sense so honest,
And this is such a certain sign ye have brought me,
That I believe.

sp.speaker: Eunuch
sp.l: Why should I cozen you?
Or were I bribed to do this villainy,
Can money prosper, or the fool that takes it,
When such a virtue falls?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ye speak well sir;
Would all the rest that serve the emperor,
Had but your way.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: And so they have ad unguem:

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pray tell my lord, I have received his token,
And will not fail to meet him; yet good sir, thus much
Before you go, I do beseech ye too,
As little notice as ye can, deliver
Of my appearance there,

sp.speaker: Eunuch
sp.l: It shall be madam,
And so I wish you happiness.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I thank you. — exeunt.

div.head: Scaen. 2.
div.stage: Enter Aecius pursuing Pontius the captain, and Maximus following.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Temper yourself Aecius,

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Hold my lord.
I am a roman, and a soldier,

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Pray sir;

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Thou art a lying villain, and a traitor;
Give me myself, or by the gods my friend
You'll make me dangerous; how dar'st thou pluck
The soldiers to sedition, and I living,
And so rebellion in 'em, and even then
When I am drawing out to action?

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Hear me,

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Are ye a man?

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: I am a true hearted Maximus,
And if the villain live, we are dishonoured.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: But hear him what he can say.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: That's the way,
To pardon him; I am so easy natured,
That if he speak but humbly I forgive him.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: I do beseech ye noble general,

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Has found the was already, give me room,
One stroke, and if he scape me then has mercy;

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: I do not call ye noble, that I fear ye,
I never cared for death; if ye will kill me,
Consider first for what, not what you can do;
'Tis true, I know ye for my general,
And by that great prerogative may kill:
But do it justly then.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: He argues with me.
By heaven a made up rebel.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Pray consider,
What certain grounds ye have for this.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: What grounds?
Did I not take him preaching to the soldiers
How lazily they lived, and what dishonours
It was to serve a prince so full of woman.
Those were his very words, friend;

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: These, Aecius,
Though they were rashly spoke, which was an error
(A great one Pontius) yet from him that hungers
For wars, and brave employment, might be pardoned.
The heart, and harboured thoughts of ill, make traitors,
Not spleeny speeches.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Why should you protect him?
Go too, it shows not honest;

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Taint me not,
For that shows worse Aecius: all your friendship
And that pretended love ye lay upon me,
Hold back my honesty, is like a favour
You do your slave today, tomorrow hang him,
Was I your bosom piece for this?

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: The nature of my zeal, and for my country,
Makes me sometimes forgive myself; for know,
Thou i most strive to be without my passions,
I am no god: for you sir, whose infection
Has spread itself like poison through the army,
And cast a killing fog on fair allegiance,
First thank this noble gentleman, ye had died else.
Next from your place, and honour of a soldier,
I here seclude you.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: May I speak yet?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Hear him:

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: And while Aecius holds a reputation,
At least command, ye bear no arms for Rome sir.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Against her I shall never: the condemnd man,
Has yet that privilege to speak my lord;
Law were not equal else.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Pray hear Aecius,
For happily the fault he has committed,
Though I believe it mighty, yet considered,
If mercy may be thought upon, will prove
Rather a hasty sin, then heinous.

sp.speaker: Aec.
sp.l: Speak.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: 'Tis true my lord, ye took me tired with peace,
My words, almost as ragged as my fortunes.
'Tis true I told the soldier, whom we served,
And then bewailed, we had an emperor
Led from us by the flourishes of fencers;
I blamed him too for women.

sp.speaker: Aec.
sp.l: To the rest sir;

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: And like enough I blessed him then as soldiers
Will do sometimes: 'tis true I told 'em too,
We lay at home, to show our country
We durst go naked, durst want meat, and money,
And when the slave drinks wine, we durst be thirsty:
I told 'em this too, that the trees and roots
Were our best paymasters; the charity
Of longing women, that had bought our bodies,
Our beds, fires, tailors, nurses, nay I told 'em,
(For you shall hear the greatest sin, I said sir)
By that time there be wars again, our bodies
Laden with scars, and aches, and ill lodgings,
Heats, and perpetual ants, were fitter prayers,
And certain graves, then cope the foe on crutches:
'Tis likely too, I counselled 'em to turn
Their warlike pikes to ploughshares, their sure targets
And swords hatched with the blood of many nations,
To spades, and pruning knives, for those get money,
Their warlike eagles, into daws, or starlings,
To give an ave Cesar as he passes,
And be rewarded with a thousand dragmas
For thus we get but years and beets.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: What think you,
Were these words to be spoken by a captain,
One that should give example?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: 'Twas too much;

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: My lord, I did not woo from the empire,
Nor bid 'em turn their daring steel 'gainst Caesar,
The gods for ever hate me, if that motion
Were part of me: give me but employment, sir;
And way to live, and where you hold me vicious,
Bred up in mutiny, my sword shall tell ye,
And if you please, that place I held, maintain it,
'Gainst the most daring foes of Rome, I am honest,
A lover of my country, one that holds
His life no longer his, then kept for Caesar.
Weigh not (I thus low on my knee beseech you)
What my rude tongue discovered, was my want,
No other part of Pontius: you have seen me,
And you my lord, do something for my country,
And both beheld the wounds I gave and took,
Not like a backward traitor.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: All this language,
Makes but against you Pontius, you are cast,
And by mine honour, and my love to Caesar,
By me shall never be restored; in my camp
I will not have a tongue, though to himself
Dare talk but near sedition; as I govern,
All shall obey, and when they want, their duty
And ready service shall redress their needs,
Not prating what they would be.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Thus I leave ye,
Yet shall my prayers still, although my fortunes
Must follow you no more, be still about ye,
Gods give ye where ye fight the victory,
Ye cannot cast my wishes.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Come my lord,
Now to the field again:

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Alas poor Pontius. — Exeunt.

div.head: Scaen. 4.
div.stage: Enter Chilax at one door, Lycinius, and Balbus at another.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: She's come,

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Then I'll to'th emperor. — exit Balbus.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Do; is the music placed well?

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Lycinius, you and Proclus receive her,
In the great chamber at her, entrance,
Let me alone; and do you hear Lycinius,
Pray let the ladies ply her further off.
And with much more discretion: one word more,

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Well;

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Are the jewels, and those ropes of pearl,
Laid in the way she passes?— enter emperor, Balbus and Proclus.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Take no care man— exeunt lyc.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: What is she come?

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: She is sir; but 'twere best,
Your grace were seen last to her,

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: So I mean;
Keep the court empty Proculus,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: 'Tis done sir.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Be not too sudden to her.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Good your grace,
Retire and man yourself; let us alone,
We are no children this way: do you hear sir?
'Tis necessary that her waiting women
Be cut off in the lobby, by some ladies,
Theed break the business else.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: 'Tis true, they shall.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Remember your place Proculus,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: I warrant ye. — Exeunt emperor, Balbus and Pro.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: She enters: who are waiters there? the emperor
Calls for his horse to air himself.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: I am glad,
I come so happily to take him absent,
This takes away a little fear; I know him,
Now I begin to fear again: o honour,
If ever thou hadst temple in weak woman.
And sacrifice of modesty burned to thee,
Hold me fast now, and help me;

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Noble madam,
Ye are welcome to the court, most nobly welcome,
Ye are a stranger lady,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I desire so;

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: A wondrous stranger here,
Nothing so strange:
And therefore need a guide I think.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I do sir,
And that a good one too.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: My service lady.
Shall be your guard in this place; but pray ye tell me,
Are ye resolved a courtier?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No I hope sir;

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: You are sir.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Yes my fair one,

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: So it seems,
You are so ready to bestow yourself,
Pray what might cost those breeches?

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Would you wear 'em,
Madam ye have a witty woman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Two sir,
Or else ye underbuy us.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Leave your talking:
But is my lord here, I beseech ye sir?

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: He is sweet lady, and must take this kindly,
Exceeding kindly of ye, wondrous kindly
Ye come so far to visit him: I'll guide ye,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Whether?

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Why to your lord,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Is it so hard sir,
To find him in this place without a guide?
For I would willingly not trouble you.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: It will be so for you that are a stranger;
Nor can it be a trouble to do service
To such a worthy beauty, and besides —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I see he will go with us.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Let him amble.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: It fits not that a lady of your reckoning,
Should pass without attendants.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I have two sir.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: I mean without a man; you'll see the emperor?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Alas I am not fit sir,

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: You are well enough.
He'll take it wondrous kindly: hark,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ye flatter,
Good sir, no more of that.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Well, I but tell ye;

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Will ye go forward, since I must be manned,
Pray take your place.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Cannot ye man us too sir?

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Give me but time.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And you'll try all things:

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: No?
Make ye no such promise,

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: If ye do sir;
Take heed ye stand to't.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Wondrous merry ladies.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The wenches are disposed, pray keep your way sir.Exit

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: She is coming up the stairs; now the music;
And as that stirs her, let's set on: perfumes there.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Discover all the jewels:

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Peace. Music.

lg.l: Now the lusty spring is seen,
All loves emblems and all cry,
Ladies, if not plucked we die.
Yet the lusty spring hath stayed,
All loves emblems and all cry,
Ladies, if not plucked we die.
What the mighty love has done,
To deceive the hopes of man,
Where no love was, loved a flower.
Hear ye ladies that are coy,
What the mighty love can do,
Fear the fierceness of the boy,
The chaste moon he makes to woe:
Ilion is a short tower higher,
He can build, and once more fire.

div.stage: Enter Chilax, Lucina, Claudia, and Marcellina.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pray heaven my lord be here, for now I fear it.
Well ring, if thou beest counterfeit, or stolen,
As by this preparation I suspect it,
Thou hast betrayed thy mistress: pray sir forward,
I would fain see my lord.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: But tell me madam,
How do ye like the song?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I like the air well,
But for the words, they are lascivious,
And overlight for ladies.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: All ours love 'em.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Tis like enough, for yours are loving ladies,

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Madam, ye are welcome to the court. Who waits?
Attendants for this lady;

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ye mistake sir;
I bring no triumph with me,

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: But much honour.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Why this was nobly done; and like a neighbour,
So freely of yourself to be a visitant,
The emperor shall give ye thanks for this.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O no sir;
There's nothing to deserve 'em,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Yes, your presence;

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Good gentlemen be patient, and believe
I come to see my husband, on command too,
I were no courtier else.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: That's all one lady,
Now ye are here, you're welcome, and the emperor
Who loves ye, but too well:

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No more of that sir.
I came not to be catechized,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Ah sirrah;
And have we got you here, saith noble lady,
We'll keep you one month courtier.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Gods defend sir,
I never liked a trade worse,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Hark ye:

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No sir;

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Ye are grown the strangest lady,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: By heaven,
'Tis true I tell ye, and you'll find it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I?
I'll rather find my grave, and so inform him.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Is it not pity gentlemen, this lady,
(Nay I'll deal roughly with ye, yet not hurt ye)
Should live alone, and give such heavenly beauty,
Only to walls, and hangings?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Good sir, patience:
I am no wonder, neither come to that end,
Ye do my lord an injury to stay me,
Who though ye are the princes, yet dare tell ye
He keeps no wife for your ways.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Well, well lady;
However you are pleased to think of us,
Ye are welcome, and ye shall be welcome;

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Show it
In that I come for then, in leading me
Where my loved lord is, not in flattery: —Jewels showed.
Nay ye may draw the curtain, I have seen 'em
But none worth half my honesty.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Are these sir,
Laid here to take?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Yes, for your lady's gentlewoman;

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We had been doing else,

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Meaner jewels
Would fit your worths;

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: And meaner clothes your bodies.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The gods shall kill me first.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: There's better dying;
I'th emperor's arms go too, but be not angry —
These are but talks sweet lady,

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.l: Where is this stranger? rushes, ladies, rushes,
Rushes as green as summer for this stranger;

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Here's ladies come to see you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You are gone then?
I take it 'tis your que,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Or rather manners,
You are better fitted madam, we but tire ye,
Therefore we'll leave you for an hour, and bring
Your much loved lord unto you— exeunt.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then I'll thank ye,
I am betrayed for certain; well Lucina,
If thou dost fall from virtue, may the earth
That after death should shout up gardens of thee,
Spreading thy living goodness into branches,
Fly from thee, and the hot sun find thy vices.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.l: You are a welcome woman;

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Bless me heaven,
How did you find the way to court?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I know not.
Would I had never trod it.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.l: Prithee tell me,
Good noble lady, and good sweet heart love us,
For we love thee extremely; is not this place
A paradise to live in?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: To those people
That know no other paradise but pleasure,
That little I enjoy contents me better,

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: What heard ye any music yet?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Too much.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.l: You must not be thus froward; what, this gown
Is one o'th prettiest by my troth Ardelia,
I ever saw yet; was not to frown in lady,
Ye put this gown on when ye came.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: How do ye?
Alas poor wretch how cold it is!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Content ye;
I am as well as may be, and as temperate,
If ye will let me be so: where's my lord?
For there's the business that I came for ladies:

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.l: We'll lead ye to him, he's i'th gallery,

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: We'll show ye all the court too.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Show me him,
And ye have showed me all I come to look on,

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.l: Come on, we'll be your guides, and as ye go,
We have some pretty tales to tell ye lady,
Shall make ye merry too; ye come not here,
To be a sad Lucina.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Would I might not. — exeunt. —

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Now the soft music; Balbus run -

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: I fly boy— exit Balbus.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: The women by this time are worming of her,— music.
If she can hold out them, the emperor
Takes her to task: he has her; hark the music:

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Good your grace,
Where are my women sir?

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: They are wise, beholding
What you think scorn to look on, the court's bravery:
Would you have run away so slily lady,
And not have seen me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I beseech your majesty,
Consider what I am, and whose,

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: I do so;

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Believe me, I shall never make a whore sir,

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: A friend ye may, and to that man that loves ye,
More than you love your virtue.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sacred Cesar,

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: You shall not kneel to me sweet,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Look upon me,
And if ye be so cruel to abuse me,
Think how the gods will take it; does this beauty
Afflict your soul? I'll hide it from you ever,
Nay more, I will become so leprous,
That ye shall curse me from ye: my dear lord,
Has served ye ever truly, fought your battles,
As if he daily longed to die for Cesar,
Was never traitor sir, nor never tainted
In all the actions of his life.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: I know it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: His fame and family have grown together,
And spread together like to sailing cedars,
Over the Roman diadem; o let not,
As ye have any flesh that's humane in you,
The having of a modest wife decline him,
Let not my virtue be the wedge to break him,
I do not think ye are lascivious,
These wanton men belie ye, you are Cesar,
Which is the father of the empire's honour,
Ye are too near the nature of the gods,
To wrong the weakest of all creatures: women.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: I dare not do it here, rise fair Lucina,
I did but try your temper, ye are honest,
And with the commendations wait on that
I'll lead ye to your lord, and ye to him:
Wipe your fair eyes: he that endeavours ill,
May well delay, but never quench his hell. — exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Chilax, Lycinius, Proculus, and Balbus.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: 'Tis done Lycinius:

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: Ho?

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: I shame to tell it,
If there be any justice, we are villains,
And must be so rewarded.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: If it be done,
I take it 'tis no time now to repent it,
Let's make the best o'th trade.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Now vengeance take it.
Why should not he have settled on a beauty,
Whose honesty stuck in a piece of tissue,
Or one a ring might rule, or such a one
That had an itching husband to be honourable,
And ground to get it: if he must have women,
And no allay without 'em, why not those
That know the misery, and are best able
To play again with judgement? such as she is,
Grant they be won with long siege, endless travel,
And brought to opportunity with millions,
Yet when they come to motion, their cold virtue
Keeps 'em like cakes of ice; I'll melt a crystal,
And make a dead flint fire himself, ere they
Give greater heat, than now departing embers
Gives to old men that watch 'em.

sp.speaker: Lyc.
sp.l: A good whore
Had saved all this, and happily as wholesome,
Ay, and the thing once done too, as well thought of,
But this same chastity forsooth,

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: A pox on't,
Why should not women be as free as we are?
They are, but not in open, and far freer,
And the more bold ye bear yourself, more welcome,
And there is nothing you dare say, but truth,
But they dare hear. —Enter emperor and Lucina.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: The emperor! away,
And if we can repent, let's home and pray. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Your only virtue now is patience,
Take heed, and save your honour; if you talk,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: As long as there is motion in my body,
And life to give me words, I'll cry for justice.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Justice shall never hear ye, I am justice,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Wilt thou not kill me, monster, ravisher,
Thou bitter bane o'th empires look upon me,
And if thy guilty eyes dare see these ruins,
Thy wild lust hath laid level with dishonour,
The sacrilegious razing of this temple,
The mother of thy black sins would have blushed at,
Behold and curse thyself; the gods will find thee,
That's all my refuge now, for they are righteous,
Vengeance and horror circle thee; the empire,
In which thou livest a strong continued surfeit,
Like poison will disgorge thee, good men raze thee
For ever being read again, — but vicious
Women, and fearful maids, make vows against thee:
Thy own slaves, if they hear of this, shall hate thee;
And those thou hast corrupted first fall from thee;
And if thou lettest me live, the soldier,
Tired with thy tyrannies, break through obedience,
And shake his strong steel at thee.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: This prevails not;
Nor any agony ye utter lady,
If I have done a sin, curse her that drew me,
Curse the first cause, the witchcraft that abused me,
Curse those fair eyes, and curse that heavenly beauty,
And curse your being good too.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Glorious thief,
What restitution canst thou make to save me?

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: I'll ever love, and honour you.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Thou canst not,
For that which was mine honour, thou hast murdered,
And can there be a love in violence?

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: You shall be only mine.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Yet I like better
Thy villainy, than flattery, that's thine own,
The other basely counterfeit; fly from me,
Or for thy safety's sake and wisdom kill me,
For I am worse than thou art; thou mayst pray,
And so recover grace; I am lost for ever,
And if thou lets't me live, thou'rt lost thyself too

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: I fear no loss but love, I stand above it.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Call in your lady bawds, and guilded panders
And let them triumph too, and sing to Cesar,
Lucina's fallen, the chaste Lucnia's conquered;
Gods, what a wretched thing has this man made me?
For I am now no wife for Maximus,
No company for women that are virtuous,
No family I now can claim, nor country,
Nor name, but Caesar's whore; oh sacred Cesar,
(For that should be your title) was your empire,
Your rods, and axes, that are types of justice,
Those fires that ever burn, to beg you blessings,
The people's adoration, fear of nations,
What victory can bring ye home, what else
The useful elements can make your servants,
Even light itself, and suns of light, truth, justice,
Mercy, and starlike piety sent to you,
And from the gods themselves to ravish women?
The curses that I owe to enemies,
Even those the Sabines sent, when Romulus,
(As thou hast me) ravished their noble maids,
Made more, and heavier, light on thee.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: This helps not.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: The sins of Tarquin be remembered in thee,
And where there has a chaste wife been abused,
Let it be thine, the shame thine, thine the slaughter,
And last for ever, thine, the feared example.
Where shall poor virtue live, now I am fallen?
What can your honours now, and empire make me,
But a more glorious whore?

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: A better woman,
But if ye will be blind, and scorn it, who can help it?
Come leave these lamentations, they do nothing,
But make a noise, I am the same man still,
Were it to do again; therefore be wiser,
By all this holy light, I should attempt it,
Ye are so excellent, and made to ravish,
There were no pleasure in ye else.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: O villain.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: So bred for man's amazement, that my reason
And every help to hold me right has lost me;
The god of love himself had been before me,
Had he but power to see ye; tell me justly,
How can I choose but err then? if ye dare,
Be mine, and only mine, for ye are so precious,
I envy any other should enjoy ye,
Almost look on ye; and your daring husband
Shall know has kept an offering from the empire,
Too holy for his altars; be the mightiest,
More than myself I'll make it: if ye will not,
Sit down with this, and silence, for which wisdom,
Ye shall have use of me, and much honour ever,
And be the same you were; if ye divulge it,
Know I am far above the faults I do,
And those I do I am able to forgive too;
And where your credit in the knowledge of it,
May be with gloss enough suspected, mine
Is as mine own command shall make it:
Princes though they be sometime subject to loose whispers,
Yet wear they two edged swords for open censures:
Your husband cannot help ye, nor the soldier,
Your husband is my creature, they my weapons,
And only where I bid 'em, strike; I feed 'em,
Nor can the gods be angry at this action,
For as they make me most, they mean me happiest,
Which I had never been without this pleasure:
Consider, and farewell: you'll find your women
At home before ye, they have had some sport too,
But are more thankful for it— exit emperor.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Destruction find thee.
Now which way must I go? my honest house
Will shake to shelter me, my husband fly me,
My family, because they are honest, and desire to be so,
Must not endure me, not a neighbour know me:
What woman now dare see me without blushes,
And pointing as I pass, there, there, behold her,
Look on her little children, that is she,
That handsome lady, mark; oh my sad fortunes,
Is this the end of goodness, this the price
Of all my early prayers to protect me,
Why then I see there is no god but power,
Nor virtue now alive that cares for us,
But what is either lame or sensual,
How had I been thus wretched else? Enter Maximus and Aecius

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Let Tituis
Command the company that Pontius lost,
And see the fosses deeper.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: How now sweet heart,
What make you here, and thus?

sp.speaker: Aeci:
sp.l: Lucina weeping?
This must be much offence,

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Look up and tell me,
Why are you thus? My ring? O friend, I have found it,
Ye were at court, sweet,

sp.speaker: Luc
sp.l: Yes, this brought me thither.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Rise, and go home: I have my fears Aecius:
O my best friend, I am ruined; go Lucina,
Already in thy tears, I have read thy wrongs,
Already found a Cesar; go thou lily,
Thou sweetly drooping flower: go silver swan,
And sing thine own sad requiem: go Lucina,
And if thou dar'st, out live this wrong.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I dare not.

sp.speaker: Aec.
sp.l: Is that the ring ye lost?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: That, that, Aecius,
That cursed ring, myself, and all my fortunes:
T'has pleased the emperor, my noble master,
For all my services, and dangers for him,
To make me mine own pandar, was this justice?
O my Aecius, have I lived to bear this?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Farewell for ever sir.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: That's a sad saying,
But such a one becomes ye well Lucina:
And yet methinks we should not part so lightly,
Our loves have been of longer growth, more rooted
Than the sharp word of one farewell can scatter.
Kiss me: I find no Cesar here; these lips
Taste not of ravisher in my opinion.
Was it not so?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O yes,

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: I dare believe thee,
For thou wert ever truth itself, and sweetness:
Indeed she was Aecius.

sp.speaker: Aec.
sp.l: So she is still.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Once more: oh my Lucina; o my comfort,
The blessing of my youth, the life of my life.

sp.speaker: Aec.
sp.l: I have seen enough to stagger my obedience:
Hold me ye equal gods, this is too sinful.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Why wert thou chosen out to make a whore of?
To me thou wert too chaste: fall crystal fountains,
And ever feed your streams you rising sorrows,
Till you have dropped your mistress into marble.
Now go for ever from me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Long farewell sir.
And as I have been loyal, gods think on me.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Stay, let me once more bid farewell Lucina,
Farewell thou excellent example of us,
Thou starry virtue, fare-thee-well, seek heaven,
And there by Cassiopeia shine in glory.
We are too base and dirty to preserve thee.

sp.speaker: Aec.
sp.l: Nay, I must kiss too: such a kiss again,
And from a woman of so ripe a virtue,
Aecius must not take: farewell thou phoenix,
If thou wilt die Lucina; which well weighed
If you can cease a while from these strange thoughts,
I wish were rather altered.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Aec.
sp.l: Mistake not.
I would not stain your honour for the empire,
Nor any way decline you to discredit,
'Tis not my fair profession, but a villain's:
I find and feel your loss as deep as you do,
And am the same Aecius, still as honest,
The same life I have still for Maximus,
The same sword wear for you, where justice wills me,
And 'tis no dull one: therefore misconceive not:
Only I would have you live a little longer,
But a short year.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: She must not.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Why so long sir,
Am I not grey enough with grief already?

sp.speaker: Aec.
sp.p: To draw from that wild man a sweet repentance, and goodness in his days to come.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: They are so,
And will be ever coming my Aecius.

sp.speaker: Aec.
sp.l: For who knows but the sight of you, presenting
His swollen sins at the full, and your fair virtues,
May like a fearful vision fright his follies,
And once more bend him right again, which blessing
(If your dark wrongs would give you leave to read)
Is more than death, and the reward more glorious:
Death, only eases you; this, the whole empire.
Besides compelled, and forced with violence,
To what ye have done, the deed is none of yours,
No nor the justice neither; ye may live,
And still a worthier woman, still more honoured:
For are those trees the worse we tear the fruits from?
Or should the eternal god's desire to perish,
Because we daily violate their truths,
Which is the chastity of heaven? No lady.
If ye dare live, ye may: and as our sins
Makes them more full of equity and justice,
So this compulsive wrong, makes you more perfect:
The empire too will bless ye.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Noble sir;
If she were any thing to me but honour,
And that that's wedded to me too, laid in
Not to be worn away without my being:
Or could the wrong be hers alone, or mine,
Or both our wrongs, not tide to after issues,
Not born a new in all our names and kindreds,
I would desire her live, nay more, compel her:
But since it was not youth, but malice did it,
And not her own, nor mine, but both our losses,
Nor stays it there, but that our names must find it,
Even those to come; and when they read, she lived,
Must they not ask how often she was ravished,
And make a doubt she loved that more than wedlock?
Therefore she must not live.

sp.speaker: Aec.
sp.l: Therefore she must live,
To teach the world such deaths are superstitious.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The tongues of angels cannot alter me;
For could the world again restore my credit,
As fair and absolute as first I bred it,
That world I should not trust again. The empire
By my life can get nothing but my story,
Which whilst I breathe must be but his abuses:
And where ye council me to live, that Cesar
May see his errors, and repent, I'll tell ye,
His penitence is but increase of pleasures,
His prayers never said but to deceive us,
And when he weeps, as you think for his vices,
'Tis but as killing drops from baleful ewgh trees
That rot their honest neighbour: if he can grieve,
As one that yet desires his free conversion,
And almost glories in his penitence,
I'll leave him robes to mourn in, my sad ashes.

sp.speaker: Aec.
sp.l: The farewells then of happy souls be with thee,
And to thy memory be ever sung
The praises of a just and constant lady,
This sad day whilst I live, a soldier's tears
I'll offer on thy monument, and bring
Full of thy noble self with tears untold yet,
Many a worthy wife, to weep thy ruin,

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: All that is chaste, upon thy tomb shall flourish,
All living epitaphs be thine, time, story;
And what is left behind to piece our lives,
Shall be no more abused with tales and trifles,
But full of thee, stand to eternity.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Once more farewell, go find Elysium,
There where the happy souls are crowned with blessings,
There where 'tis ever spring, and ever summer.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: There where no bedrid justice comes; truth, honour,
Are keeper of that blessed place; go thither,
For here thou livest chaste fire in rotten timber.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: And so our last farewells.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Gods give the justice. — exit Lucina.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: His thoughts begin to work; I fear him, yet
He ever was a noble Roman, but
I know not what to think on't, he hath suffered
Beyond a man, if he stand this.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Aecius,
Am I alive , or has a dead sleep seized me?
It was my wife the emperor abused thus;
And I must say, I am glad I had her for him;
Must I not my Aecius?

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: I am stricken
With such a stiff amazement, that no answer
Can readily come from me, nor no comfort:
Will ye go home, or go to my house?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Neither:
I have no home, and you are mad Aecius
To keep me company, I am a fellow
My own sword would forsake, not tied unto me:
A pandar is a prince, to what I am fallen;
By heaven I dare do nothing.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Ye do better.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: I am made a branded slave Aecius ▪
And yet I bless the maker;
Death o my soul, must I endure this tamely?
Must Maximus be mentioned for his tales?
I am a child too; what should I do railing?
I cannot mend myself, 'tis Caesar did it,
And what am I to him?

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: 'Tis well considered;
However you are tainted, be no traitor.
Time may outwear the first, the last lives ever.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: O that thou wert not living, and my friend.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: I'll bear a wary eye upon your actions,
I fear ye Maximus, nor can I blame thee
If thou breakest out, for by the gods thy wrong
Deserves a general ruin: do ye love me?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: That's all I have to live on.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Then go with me,
Ye shall not to your own house.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Nor to any,
My griefs are greater far, than walls can compass,
And yet I wonder how it happens with me,
I am not dangerous, and o my conscience
Should I now see the emperor i'th hear on't,
I should not chide him for't, an awe runs through me,
I feel it sensibly that binds me to it,
'Tis at my heart now, there it sits and rules,
And methinks 'tis a pleasure to obey it.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: This is a mask to cozen me; I know ye,
And how far ye dare do; no Roman farther,
Nor with more fearless valour; and I'll watch ye:
Keep that obedience still.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Is a wife's loss
(For her abuse much good may do his grace,
I'll make as bold with his wife, if I can)
More than the fading of a few fresh colours,
More than a lusty spring lost?

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: No more Maximus,
To one that truly lives.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Why then I care not, I can live well enough Aecius.
For look you friend, for virtue, and those trifles,
They may be bought they say.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: He's crazes a little.
His grief has made him talk things from his nature.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: But chastity is not a thing I take it
To get in Rome, unless it be bespoken
A hundred year before; is it Aecius?
By'r lady, and well handled too i'th breeding.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Will ye go any way?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: I'll tell thee friend.
If my wife for all this should be a whore now,
A kind of kicker out of sheets, 'twould vex me,
For I am not angry yet; the emperor
Is young and handsome, and the woman flesh,
And may not these two couple without scratching?

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Alas my noble friend.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Alas not me,
I am not wretched, for there's no man miserable
But he that makes himself so:

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Will ye walk yet?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Come, come, she dare not die friend, that's the truth on't,
She knows the enticing sweet and delicacies
Of a young princes' pleasures, and I thank her
She has made a way for Maximus to rise by?
Wilt not become me bravely? why do you think
She wept, and said she was ravished? keep it here
And I'll discover to you.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: She knows
I love no bitten flesh, and out of that hope
She might be from me, she contrived this knavery;
Was it not monstrous friend?

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Does he but seem so,
Or is he made indeed?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: O gods, my heart!

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Would it would fairly break.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Methinks I am somewhat wilder than I was,
And yet I thank the gods I know my duty -Enter Claudia.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Nay ye may spare your tears; she's dead.
She is so.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Why so it should be: how?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: When first she entered
Into her house, after a world of weeping,
And blushing like the sunset, as we see her;
Dare I said she defile this house with whore,
In which his noble family has flourished?
At which she fell, and stirred no more; we rubbed her. Exit Clau.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: No more of that: be gone: now my Aecius,
If thou wilt do me pleasure, weep a little,
I am so parched I cannot: your example
Has brought the rain down now: now lead me friend,
And as we walk together let's pray together truly
I may not fall from faith.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: That's nobly spoken.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Was I not wild, Aecius?

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Somewhat troubled.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: I felt no sorrow then: now I'll go with ye,
But do not name the woman: fie what fool
Am I to weep thus? God's Lucina take thee,
For thou wert even the best, and worthiest lady.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Good sir no more, I shall be melted with it.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: I have done, and good sir comfort me
Would there were wars now.

sp.speaker: Aeci.
sp.l: Settle your thoughts, come.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: So I have now friend,
Of my deep lamentations here's an end. — exeunt.

sp.speaker: Phidias
sp.l: By my faith captain Pontius, besides pity
Of your fall'n fortunes, what to say I know not,
For 'tis too true the emperor desires not
But my best master, any soldier near him:

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: And when he understands, he cast your fortunes
For disobedience, how can we incline him,
(That are but under persons to his favours)
To any fair opinion? Can ye sing?

sp.speaker: Pontius
sp.l: Not to please him Aretius, for my songs
Go not to'th lute, or viol, but to'th trumpet,
My tune kept on a target, and my subject
The well struck wounds of men, not love, or women.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: And those he understands not.

sp.speaker: Pont.
sp.l: He should Phidias,

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Could you not leave this killing way a little?
You must if here you would plant yourself, and rather
Learn as we do, to like what those affect
That are above us: wear their actions,
And thinks they keep us warm too: what they say,
Though oftentimes they speak a little foolishly,
Not stay to construe, but prepare to execute,
And think however the end falls, the business
Cannot run empty handed.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Can ye flatter,
And if it were put to you, lie a little?

sp.speaker: Pont.
sp.l: Yes, if it be a living.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: That's well said then:

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: But must these lies and flatteries be believed then?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O yes by any means.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: By any means then,
I cannot lie, nor flatter.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: Ye must swear too,
If ye be there.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: I can swear, if they move me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Cannot ye forswear too.

sp.speaker: Pont.
sp.l: The court for ever,
If it be grown so wicked.

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: You should procure a little too,

sp.speaker: Pont.
sp.l: What's that?
Men's honest sayings for my truth?

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: O no sir:
But women's honest actions for your trial.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Do you do all these things?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Do you not like 'em?

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Do ye ask me seriously, or trifle with me?
I am not so low yet, to be your mirth:

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: You do mistake us captain, for sincerely,
We ask you how you like 'em.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Then sincerely
I tell ye I abhor 'em: they are ill ways,
And I will starve before I fall into 'em.
The doers of 'em wretches, their base hungers
Cares not whose bread they eat, nor how they get it:

sp.speaker: Are.
sp.l: What then sir?

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: If you profess this wickedness:
Because ye have been soldiers, and born arms,
The servants of the brave Aecius,
And by him put to'th emperor, give me leave,
Or I must take it else, to say ye are villains,
For all your golden coats, debauched, base villains,
Yet I do wear a sword to tell ye so,
Is this the way you mark out for a soldier,
A man that has commanded for the empire,
And born the reputation of a man?
Are there not lazy things enough called fools, and cowards,
And poor enough to be preferred for panders,
But wanting soldiers must be knave too? ha:
This the trim course of life: were not ye born bawds,
And so inherit but your rights? I am poor
And may expect a worse; yet digging, pruning,
Mending of broken ways, carrying of water,
Planting of words, and onions, any thing
